description.plain:
Coldplay is a British rock band, formed in 1997 by University College London classmates Chris Martin (vocals, guitar, piano), Jonny Buckland (guitar) and Guy Berryman (bass), along with drummer Will Champion. The band’s name comes from Tim Crompton, a student who was in the same university as the members (University College London) at the time. They were previously known as Pectoralz, then changed their name to Starfish in 1997 before finally settling on the name Coldplay.

Once they issued their debut, Parachutes in 2000, many saw them as a Radiohead knock-off. No doubt, Coldplay’s sound —elegant, melodic, vaguely spacey and very dramatic — bore plenty of similarity to mid-1990s Radiohead. But the group’s hooks, sharpened by frontman Chris Martin’s ability to pull heartstrings, and the their willingness to evolve their sound, gave Coldplay staying power. The greatest examples are second album A Rush of Blood to the Head (2002), which was generally considered to be musically and lyrically more mature and sophisticated, and less obviously the product of one particular influence, and the fourth one Viva La Vida or Death and All His Friends (2008), where producer Brian Eno influenced the band to broaden their sound and led to various sonic landscapes. Both won the Grammy Award for Best Rock Album and spawned sucessful singles such as “Clocks”, “Viva la Vida”, “In My Place”, “Violet Hill” and “The Scientist”.
Coldplay also proved they can use truly rock sounds in their albums, as shown in X&Y, and juggle with more electronics albums like Mylo Xyloto, Ghost Stories or A Head Full of Dreams.

As a result, the band became one of the most commercially successful acts of the new millennium, with over 80 million albums sold – even if along with the acclaim came a vocal opposition, due to the supposedly derivative nature, the overtly emotional lyrics, and the fact they’re good-mannered English boys instead of wild rockstars. As a result, Coldplay are thought as either a punchline showing all that’s wrong with 21st century rock, or a really good if overplayed band with songs tailor made for stadium performances.

songs.title: The Scientist

description.plain:
“The Scientist” is a very mellow song about trying to analyze a broken relationship.

The song’s melody is inspired by “Don’t Look Back in Anger” by the Oasis, especially the piano part.

The music video is famous for its reverse chronology (which required Chris Martin to learn the song backwards in order to make it look like he was singing forwards as he walked backwards…).  Although the video fits the song well, the idea for the video came to Director Jamie Thraves independently; he then waited for the perfect song to match his concept.

songs.title: Viva la Vida

description.plain:
Revered as an essential rock song of the 2000s, “Viva La Vida” tells the story of a monarch who’s lost his kingdom. In another aspect, the song is also seen as a narrative on the French Revolution given the historical and biblical references in the lyrics. The instrumental is based around a string and piano background, led by an orchestral drum beat.

The title derives from the Spanish phrase “Long Live Life,” and takes its name from Frida Kahlo’s last painting before her death. During a March 2008 interview with Rolling Stone, frontman Chris Martin explained the reason for naming the song and album in honor of Kahlo:

She went through a lot of s–t, of course, and then she started a big painting in her house that said ‘Viva la Vida.’ I loved the boldness of it. […] It just felt right.

This song debuted to massive success and acclaim, peaking at number one on both the Billboard 100 and UK Singles Chart. Coldplay received several awards for the track, including Song of the Year at the Grammy Awards in February 2009.

The chorus has musical similarities to Joe Satriani’s instrumental piece, “If I Could Fly.” Satriani sued Coldplay for plagiarism—they settled out of court. The band Creaky Boards also accused Coldplay of taking the song’s melody from their record, “The Songs I Didn’t Write,” however, Coldplay denied the allegations.

Coldplay released two music videos for this song. Hype Williams made the official video, which premiered in August 2008, depicting the band against a backdrop of Eugène Delacroix’s painting, Liberty Leading the People. The alternate music video dropped alongside the first one but was directed by Anton Corbijn and starred Chris Martin as a king.

songs.title: Fix You

description.plain:
“Fix You” is the fourth track and second single from Coldplay’s third album X&Y. It was written by Chris Martin for his then-wife, Gwyneth Paltrow, to comfort her after her father passed away.

The song has been covered numerous times, including notable renditions by the Young@Heart chorus in the award-winning 2007 documentary, as well as pop icon Sam Smith, and Korean septet BTS.

songs.title: Yellow

description.plain:
“Yellow” is the fifth track and second single from Coldplay’s 2000 debut album Parachutes. It is their oldest and its most enduring hit, continuing to be a celebrated staple of live performances even today.

The title of the song came from the feel of the band during its composition, which was described as filled with “brightness and hope and devotion.” However, the lyrical content was inspired by lead singer Chris Martin’s “unrequited love”.

(Source: Coldplay: Nobody Said It Was Easy by Martin Roach)

songs.full_title: Hymn for the Weekend by Coldplay (Ft. Beyoncé)
songs.title: Hymn for the Weekend

description.plain:
Coldplay’s Queen B duet is an ode to enjoying a significant other you love and cherish. In an interview, Martin described the origins of the collaboration and its sound:

I thought I’d like to have a song called “Drinks on Me” where you sit on the side of a club and buy everyone drinks because you’re so fucking cool. I was chuckling about that, when this melody came – “drinks on me, drinks on me” – then the rest of the song came out. I presented it to the rest of the band and they said, “We love this song, but there’s no way you can sing ‘drinks on me.’” So that changed into “drink from me” and the idea of having an angelic person in your life. Then that turned into asking Beyonce to sing on it.

It’s one of four collaborations on the album; the others are Tove Lo on “Fun”, Gwyneth Paltrow on “Everglow”, and a Barack Obama sample on “Kaleidoscope.”

Apparently, Beyonce also made their album 90% better.

She made our album 90% better. And we were already 20% good. So now we’re like 110% the band we used to be. You do the math.

Before the album’s December 4, 2015 release date, it was previewed on Twitter on November 24, 2015. The official music video was uploaded on the 29th of January.

songs.full_title: A Sky Full of Stars by Coldplay
songs.title: A Sky Full of Stars

description.plain:
One of Coldplay’s most hyped tracks ever, described by attendees of Coldplay’s secret Ghost Stories shows as “wonderfully produced” and “upbeat, happy, makes you want to stand up and dance,” “A Sky Full of Stars” is the centerpiece of Ghost Stories, bringing the emotional treadmill to an explosive climax.

The track was released as Coldplay’s second single from Ghost Stories, after “Magic,” with the track premiering on 29 April 2014.

EDM artist Avicii was a primary producer on the track and Chris Martin later revealed in an interview that he asked the producer to play the piano parts.

songs.title: Everglow

description.plain:
The most personal and emotionally-charged song on Coldplay’s enigmatic A Head Full of Dreams, “Everglow” expresses memory and loss as an ever-lasting “glow.”

Most likely inspired by his own divorce from actress Gwyneth Paltrow, songwriter Chris Martin stated during an interview with Zane Lowe:

To me, [the song] is about — whether it’s a loved one or a situation or a friend or a relationship that’s finished, or someone’s passed away — I was thinking about, after you’ve been through the sadness of something, you also get this everglow. That’s what it’s about.

songs.full_title: Adventure of a Lifetime by Coldplay
songs.title: Adventure of a Lifetime

description.plain:
The groovy fifth track on Coldplay’s dynamic A Head Full of Dreams takes a step into disco, with a simplistic song about life and love, backed by a funky dance floor beat. It features a prominent guitar riff that was inspired by the riff on Guns N' Roses “Sweet Child O' Mine.”

According to bassist Guy Berryman,

[The track] started as a freeform musical session and was called something else, Legends or something. It had a different chord sequence and different hooks and one-by-one things were taken away and things got added.

songs.title: Paradise

description.plain:
The third track and lead single off Mylo Xyloto, Coldplay makes a true masterpiece of the song “Paradise”. With its jittery synths, orchestral hooks, thunderous drumming, and falsetto vocals by frontman Chris Martin, this is a win-win for everyone; critics and fans alike.

The song is about how the real world can be escaped through dreams and paradise. In context of the album’s concept, it shows how the rebel leader Fly is just some shuteye away. The song describes her obstacles in life, and how she first noticed that the government system in Silencia is corrupted, due to Major Minus.

songs.title: Clocks

description.plain:
Continuing the existential themes of A Rush of Blood to the Head, “Clocks” opens with a haunting piano melody into Chris Martin’s falsetto vocals.

The song concerns the paradox facing humanity: an obsession with time and punctuality versus a desire to savor every moment and “seize the day.” The lyrics speak to this universal existential anxiety.

 Several remixes exist of the song, and there are many samples of the piano riff used throughout the song. “Clocks” was well received by critics and even won “Record of the Year” at the 2004 Grammy Awards.

songs.title: Sparks

description.plain:
“Sparks” is an acoustic song by the British rock band Coldplay. It’s the fourth track off of Coldplay’s debut album, Parachutes.

This acoustic love song is about a person who tries to get someone to remember them again. They go on about their relationship, and how he saw “sparks” of love when they were together.

body.plain:
“Sparks” is an acoustic song by the British rock band Coldplay. It’s the fourth track off of Coldplay’s debut album, Parachutes.

This acoustic love song is about a person who tries to get someone to remember them again. They go on about their relationship, and how he saw “sparks” of love when they were together.

songs.title: Orphans

description.plain: The co-lead single from Everyday Life and lead single from ‘Sunset’, the second part of the double album, “Orphans”, tackles the Syrian Civil War. It showcases the story of a girl (Rosaleem) and her Baba (Arabic for father) who are now refugees and are met by what they believe to be the archangels, which is most probably someone aiding them in the refugee crisis.

songs.title: Magic

description.plain:
The lead single of Coldplay’s sixth studio album Ghost Stories, “Magic,” introduces us to the narrator’s former relationship with a woman he loved in a magical way. Through clever references to the art of stage magic, he describes a very special bond that once existed between the two.

The song is not an affirmation of a relationship, it is a song about honoring yourself when a relationship ends. Although his lover has broken him in two by ending the relationship, he celebrates the magic of his capacity to unconditionally love another, even if they don’t reciprocate — his precious jewel.

songs.title: Everyday Life

description.plain:
The closing track off Everyday Life showcases a slow piano ballad that describes and summarizes the band’s general album message: love, equality, pain, struggles, legacy, humanity, hope, everyday life.
It follows how everyone is different but we’re all part of the same big family.

The main chord progression, F#m – A – Em – Bm, is the same as that of album opener Church.

songs.title: Higher Power

description.plain:
“Higher Power” is a song that arrived on a little keyboard and a bathroom sink at the start of 2020 and was mentioned briefly during the TogetherAtHome livestreamed concerts. According to Chris Martin, “the song is about trying to find the astronaut in all of us, the person that can do amazing things”.

On April 30th, the band inadvertently released an advert of the song with a snippet of the music a week early, which was quickly deleted 30 minutes after it was posted.  On May 3rd, a post was made on the official Coldplay TikTok featuring a new clip of the song, lasting 26 seconds.

The song was finally released on May 7th, alongside an online conference with French astronaut Thomas Pesquet, who was aboard the ISS. Martin explained to him:

Right now we aren’t able to play for anybody on Earth, so we thought we’d just play for you.

songs.title: Up&Up

description.plain:
In the dramatic and uplifting grand finale of Coldplay’s enigmatic A Head Full of Dreams, the band presents us with a power ballad that encourages belief and optimism in both life and love, through emphasis on hardships and empowering music led by a melancholy piano riff, seemingly inspired by the likes of Train and other big-sound rock bands of the early 2000s.

Touted by Chris Martin as “the song that they’ve been waiting to write for fifteen years”, the song not only represents a beautiful conclusion to A Head Full of Dreams, but also a chapter in the life of Coldplay themselves, with Martin having noted the album as “the completion of something.”

This song actually has two music videos: the first video was done in the UK, but Martin ended up hating it and the label thought it was too dark for American audiences; the second video is much more light-hearted.

songs.title: Arabesque

description.plain:
The co-lead single “Arabesque” (which is the lead single for the Sunrise part of the album) is Coldplay’s way of trying to sew peace in the wake of the western fear of Islam with the war on terrorism going on. Instrumentally, the song merges western musical styles with Middle Eastern rhythms (like with the guitar & saxophone) placing the idea that “music unites us all”.

Arabesque is a visual art genre, which was mostly used in Islamic countries. For example, in architecture, it’s an ornamental design consisting of intertwined flowing lines, originally found in ancient Islamic art. While in dance and ballet, it is a dancing posture. The name of the songs is very apropos to the whole theme of the album being Arabic and bringing the culture to western media. The meaning of the track is also parallel and similar to the song “بنی آدم (Son of Adam)” by the Persian poet, Sadi.

songs.title: Hypnotised

description.plain:
“Hypnotised” is a “dreamlike ballad” from the British rock band Coldplay’s 2017 EP, Kaleidoscope. It is the second song from the EP to be announced, and is the fifth track on what will be a five track EP, planned for release on June 2, 2017.

Described as a “non-single” by the group, it was announced on the official Coldplay site on the March 2, 2017, coinciding with lead singer Chris Martin’s 40th birthday, and in anticipation of the EP’s release on June 2. It can be listened to via most of the mainstream music services.

https://twitter.com/coldplay/status/837210972817219584

The track was released alongside what writers described as being “a captivating lyric video” directed by Mary Wigmore. Chris Martin said the following about the release of “Hypnotised:”

“Hypnotised” won’t necessarily be a “single,” as much as it simply the first offering from the EP.

A snippet of the song was teased the day before on social media. The first half of the song is reminiscent of early Coldplay providing a nice throwback for longtime fans.

songs.title: In My Place

description.plain:
The second track and first single of A Rush of Blood to the Head, “In My Place” won the award for Best Rock Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal at the 45th Annual Grammy Awards.

Thematically, it speaks of the inevitably unchangeable characteristics present in all humans. Chris warns listeners from letting these flaws deteriorate relationships with loved ones.

The song is directly related to the whole concept of the album and the song “A Rush of Blood to the Head” : the mental state the singer is in, his impulsive behaviours, his insecurities, and all the lack of emotional intelligence in his characteristics. In this song, he asks his significant other to understand him and the place and state he is in because he feels lost.

songs.title: Violet Hill

description.plain:
“Violet Hill” is off of Coldplay’s album Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends. It was their first attempt at a protest/political song.

The first line “It was a long and dark December” was actually the first line the band ever wrote, but they could never finish the rest of the song. The rest of the song came about after watching Bill O'Reilly rant, and Chris thinking about a musician friend who worked in a bar and struggled with his boss, leading to lyrics about having your life run by people you don’t like.

songs.title: Champion of the World

description.plain:
“Champion of the World” was released as a tribute to Scott Hutchison, the lead singer of Frightened Rabbit who took his life in May 2018 after struggling with depression. The song was released on November 20th, which would’ve been Scott’s 38th birthday.

This song was inspired by Owl John’s song “Los Angeles, Be Kind.”

songs.title: Fly On

description.plain:
“Fly On” is the first of two songs that appears on the ninth and final track on Coldplay’s sixth studio album, Ghost Stories, entitled “O”. The song, “O”, itself is the ambient piece that comes after “Fly On”, for those who are confused.

Arguably one of the saddest songs written by the band, “Fly On” brings the emotional treadmill to an end, after a 40-minute spiritual journey, encapsulating the narrator’s newly-realized feelings about the woman he once called his own: Like a flock of birds, love comes and goes, and it’s not worth hurting over.

songs.title: Ink

description.plain: The emotionally scarring, yet suprisingly catchy third track off Coldplay’s sixth studio album, Ghost Stories, truly gives us an insight into the narrator’s obsession with the love he had lost. His love for the woman no longer in his life is written in ink; it cannot be removed easily, and it brings a whole lot of pain with it.

songs.title: Shiver

description.plain:
The lead single off Parachutes, “Shiver” (alongside fan favorite “Yellow”) helped establish Coldplay in the new millennium alt-rock scene. The song was recorded in one take.

Chris Martin derisively describes it as a “stalking song” in line with the likes of the Police and Jeff Buckley. According to Martin, the track was written for a specific woman in mind but never disclosed who. Many speculated that it was  Natalie Imbruglia but Martin denies this, stating her only role was visual inspiration.

songs.title: Church

description.plain:
The chord progression for “Church"— F#m – A – Em – Bm—bookends the album. It is recalled for the closing track, Everyday Life.

The song draw a thin parallelism between the beauty and heartwarming presence of a girl that makes you feel secure and safe, and a place, the “Church”, in which a strong believer can feel the same emotions of joy and unconditional safeness.

songs.title: Strawberry Swing

description.plain:
“Strawberry Swing” is the penultimate track on Viva La Vida. It was almost left off the album, but Chris Martin was adamant that the track should be included.

The track plays with the image of a ‘strawberry’ swing, an idealistic swing which is perfect only in the company of loved ones.

songs.full_title: Always in My Head by Coldplay
songs.title: Always in My Head

description.plain:
The opening track on Coldplay’s largely-anticipated sixth studio album, Ghost Stories; a haunting, ambient teardrop follow up to the band’s technicolour rock opera explosion, 2011’s Mylo Xyloto.

The song introduces the basic narrative and the two characters of Ghost Stories; a man, whose point of view is represented in this album, and a woman who he loved very much but had broken away from him.

songs.title: Green Eyes

description.plain:
The seventh track of the album, “Green Eyes” has a country-rock vibe to it.

Chris Martin wrote the song as a ballad for a former girlfriend who, obviously, had green eyes. When Chris started dating Gwyneth Paltrow in 2002, he decided against performing the song live as it offended her. Instead, he chose to play “Moses,” a song written for Paltrow.

Later he said the following about the discussion: “It’s not about the right person. It’s like an old pair of trousers, it doesn’t fit.”

description.plain:
The title track of “A Rush of Blood to the Head” deals with revenge and loss of emotional control we experience within it.

Furthermore, the British band tackle once again emotional intelligence and the ability to be conscious of our feelings and emotions. The protagonist is suffering from impulsive behaviour and he’s regretting his thoughtless actions, but blaming it upon what he calls “A rush of blood to the head.” The truth is he’s lost and unaware of how he feels.

songs.title: Midnight

description.plain:
“Midnight” was teased by Coldplay before it’s release.



It was their first (with the exception of “Atlas” for the Hunger Games soundtrack) release of new material since Mylo Xyloto in 2011. It later appeared on the band’s sixth LP, Ghost Stories.

The song represents a change in style, with Chris Martin’s heavily processed vocals being the focal point which drew comparisons to Bon Iver.

songs.title: O

description.plain:
“O,” the titular song on the ninth and final track on Coldplay’s sixth studio album Ghost Stories, brings the journey to a close with a soulful ambient piece with a voice saying, “Don’t ever let go”.

A Western-influenced guitar version of “O”, titled “O (Reprise)”, was released as the final track on the A Sky Full Of Stars EP. This song, along with the other two non-album tracks on the EP (“All Your Friends” and “Ghost Story”), were re-released as part of the Target deluxe edition of Ghost Stories.

songs.title: True Love

description.plain:
Cited as lead singer Chris Martin’s favourite track on the album, the fourth track on Coldplay’s sixth studio album Ghost Stories introduces the album’s concept of uncomfortable music, after “Ink”’s introduction of uncomfortable lyrics.

The song continues to explore the singer’s rapidly declining psychological state. He talks to the “ghost” of his love long gone, once again, and goes full-on Stockholm, stating the pain he endures is simply bliss to him.

songs.title: Coloratura

description.plain:
“Coloratura” is the twelfth and final track from Coldplay’s ninth studio album, Music of the Spheres. The 10-minute space epic takes the listener into a panoramic, multi-suite voyage into the cosmos.

The song is the second release from the album since the lead single, “Higher Power,” released in May 2021.

songs.title: Every Teardrop Is a Waterfall

description.plain:
With electronic rock mixing with progressive rock, “Every Teardrop is a Waterfall” is the first single and seventh track from Coldplay’s fifth studio album and rock opera Mylo Xyloto. Stinging synths and hard rock guitars drive this jam, with drumming taking the wheel.



Mylo knows that he might be a prophesied one, to lead the rebels, but later on, it doesn’t add up to the fact that he is still active as a Silencer.

songs.title: Charlie Brown

description.plain:
With it’s coming-of-age background and lively beat, “Charlie Brown”, the fourth track and third single off Mylo Xyloto, takes its inspiration from the famous star of Charles M. Schulz’s classic newspaper comic strip Peanuts.



Mylo steals car keys to take a car to a party, where Fly and Mylo meet and become interested in each other, and even have a thing between them that might evolve into a relationship.

songs.title: Speed of Sound

description.plain:
The song was inspired by Martin’s daughter, Apple, and English alternative rock singer Kate Bush.

That’s a song where we were listening to a lot of Kate Bush last summer, and we wanted a song which had a lot of tom-toms in it. I just had my daughter up also, and was kind of feeling in a sense of awe and wonderment, so the song is kind of a Kate Bush song about miracles.”

— Chris Martin for Yahoo! Music 5/31/2005

The final track of A Rush of Blood to the Head showcases the redemptive power of love. It was written while the band were in Amsterdam, hence the title.

It is NOT, as many have speculated, about an attempted suicide on Martin’s part.

The track, through its blissful electronic rock presentation, led by bass and guitar, and lyrics describing a world where dreams come to life, “A Head Full of Dreams” introduces the album in the wildest way possible.

songs.full_title: God Put a Smile Upon Your Face by Coldplay
songs.title: God Put a Smile Upon Your Face
songs.title_with_featured: God Put a Smile Upon Your Face

description.plain:
“God Put A Smile Upon Your Face” is the third song off of Coldplay’s second studio album, A Rush Of Blood To The Head.

The song’s meaning is that one should appreciate what they have because life is short and nobody knows what actually happens after death.

Despite Coldplay’s massive popularity at the time in the UK, the single only peaked at 100th––only promo copies were released. However, it was a top 40 hit in The Netherlands and New Zealand, and hit number three in Poland.

songs.title: Christmas Lights

description.plain:
Marked by a somber mood, Coldplay’s anthem for Christmas is one that metaphorizes the lights and decorations of the festive season as beacons of warmth and hope for those feeling left in the cold during Christmas. The song follows a first-person perspective of a person mourning the verbally violent breakup of a relationship on Christmas Eve, with the heartening spirit of the holidays to guide him and others to a happier and merrier Christmas, as it should be.

Originally released in December 2010 as a surprise, straight from the recording sessions that would spawn the technicolor marvel known as Mylo Xyloto, “Christmas Lights”, for its festive themes, has been a recurring staple of Christmas celebrations for Coldplay fans each December.

songs.title: Lost!

description.plain:
“Lost!” is an anthemic track about perseverance. It tells how people might believe one is lost when everything is actually thriving.

Fun fact: all the versions of the track have different symbols attached to them.


“Lost?” is an acoustic version on piano (released as a Viva la Vida bonus track and as the B-side for the “Violet Hill” single)
“Lost@” is a live version recorded at the United Center in Chicago; a recording of this performance was used for the music video
“Lost+” is a remix featuring Jay-Z; the rapper is a friend of frontman Chris Martin
“Lost-” is the instrumental version of the album track

songs.title: Talk

description.plain:
“Talk” is the third single from Coldplay’s third album, X&Y. It features lyrics about feeling insecure and how conversation could fix it, and  a recurring melodic hook directly inspired by the synth motif prevalent in Kraftwerk’s “Computer Love”.



Commercially, it was a success, reaching number one in Poland and the Netherlands and the top ten in Spain and UK. In the US, it hit the top ten of Alternative and Adult Pop Songs, and topped the Hot Dance Club songs.

songs.title: بنی آدم

description.plain:
“بنی آدم (Children of Adam)” is a song inspired by the Persian poem of the same name (or sometimes also called “Bani Adam”) by Saadi Shirazi. The poem in English reads:

Humans (Children of Adam) are inherent parts (or more literally, limbs) of one body, and are from the same valuable essence (or more literally, gem) in their creation.
When the conditions of the time hurt one of these parts, other parts will be disturbed.
If you are indifferent about the misery of others,
it may not be appropriate to call you a human being.



The word بنی (bani) is the plural form of ابن (ibn) in Arabic which means son. However, in this poem, the intention of Saadi was the whole humankind and the “Children of Adam” would give a more appropriate meaning to the content.

songs.title: Another’s Arms

description.plain:
The morbid sixth track on Coldplay’s sixth studio album, Ghost Stories, sees the man at the centre of the story go deeper into his emotions. While he tries to forget about the woman he no longer has, he starts to reminisce about the times the two had together instead.

The track was one of the few songs from Ghost Stories to have been teased before the album’s release, as it was performed alongside “Always in My Head” in the run-up to the release day.

songs.title: Til Kingdom Come

description.plain:
The hidden track of X&Y, “‘Til Kingdom Come” was originally intended to be a collaboration with Johnny Cash, but he died before his part could be recorded – this explains why the song has a very country vibe to it (Rihanna would later have the “honor” of being Coldplay’s first collaboration on an LP).

At its core, “‘Til Kingdom Come” is a ballad about Death coming to claim a man at the end of his life (a fitting theme given that Cash was close to death himself). When played at live performances, the band usually combine the song with Cash’s “Ring of Fire.”

songs.title: BrokEn

description.plain:
On “BrokEn,” Chris Martin leads a gospel choir in a simple call-and-response structure, backed only by a piano and some finger snaps.

Coldplay dedicated this song to Brian Eno, former producer of the band. In the official release of the lyrics, it says: “For Brian Eno. With love and thanks”. The letters “B” and “E” in the title are capitalized for his initials.

songs.title: Hurts Like Heaven

description.plain:
Continuing from Mylo Xyloto, Hurts Like Heaven continues the story of Mylo and Xyloto, and opens up the world to the listener, as well as early life. With 1984 8-bit synths, amazing drumming, refrained bass hooks, distorted and high-hitting guitars, and the best vocals from Chris Martin, the song will rivet you through damnation and back, as it talks about the oppression of government, rebellion, and love, with Silencia turning into a living hell.



Talking through the early points of Mylo’s life, his parents were affiliated with a sparker gang known as the “Car Kids”. Through the course of the song, it talks about their struggles, and their eventual capturing, leaving Mylo emotionally unstable since the witnessing, and his parents to rot in jail.

“Gravity” is a rare Coldplay song; first performed live in 2002, then later, Chris Martin gave the song to British band Embrace.

The lyrics talk about a relationship between two individuals and uses gravity as a metaphor for their love. The song is built around a piano, acoustic guitar, drums and background synths.

songs.title: Lovers in Japan / Reign of Love
songs.title_with_featured: Lovers in Japan / Reign of Love

description.plain:
“Lovers in Japan” is the fifth track and third single of Viva la Vida. On the LP this track is coupled to “Reign of Love.”

In an interview for Entertainment Weekly in 2008, lead singer Chris Martin, when talking about the song and its title, remarked that “No one associates romance with Japan…Everyone thinks Japan is just about Hitachi and neon signs, but every time we’re there, we see these amazing sunrises. It’s very sexy.”

A slightly uptempo version of this song (the “Osaka Sun Mix”) appeared on Prospekt’s March.

An acoustic version also appeared as an iTunes pre-order bonus track.

annotatable.title: Lovers in Japan / Reign of Love

body.plain:
“Lovers in Japan” is the fifth track and third single of Viva la Vida. On the LP this track is coupled to “Reign of Love.”

In an interview for Entertainment Weekly in 2008, lead singer Chris Martin, when talking about the song and its title, remarked that “No one associates romance with Japan…Everyone thinks Japan is just about Hitachi and neon signs, but every time we’re there, we see these amazing sunrises. It’s very sexy.”

A slightly uptempo version of this song (the “Osaka Sun Mix”) appeared on Prospekt’s March.

An acoustic version also appeared as an iTunes pre-order bonus track.

songs.title: Atlas

description.plain:
Coldplay release a song from the official soundtrack of the highly anticipated sequel in the The Hunger Games franchise, Catching Fire. The single was released on iTunes on August 26.



The song title refers to to The Titan, Atlas, who carries the world on his shoulders, and is also the god of astronomy and navigation.

songs.title: Guns

description.plain: The opener for the second part of the album, Sunset (غروب), starts with “Guns”, a track that criticizes American’s love for guns and how people have been led to believe that gun violence is fixed with arming everyone instead of regulating guns themselves. The track continues to project the theme of the album with a message of peace by highlighting the problem the United States has with the second amendment and the growing mass-shootings in the country.

songs.title: Old Friends

description.plain:
Old Friends is the fifth song on the “Sunset” half of Coldplay’s eighth studio album Everyday Life.

The song is about Chris Martin’s childhood best friend named Tony. The song also works as a ode to friendship, and the friends who eventually drift out of your life after leaving a good impact on you.

songs.title: Flags

description.plain:
“Flags” is a bonus track included on the Japanese version of the album Everyday Life. It points out how borders and flags can’t divide people since they are all from the same essence and soul. The song refers to every person individually, free from their geographical differences and sexual preferences.

One year after its release, the song was released worldwide on December 21, 2020, with the band stating that they love the song, but did not have space for it on the standard tracklist of Everyday Life.

songs.title: The Hardest Part

description.plain: “The Hardest Part” is about the ending of a long and loving relationship, and the feelings that are left behind when the person is gone. The lyrics talk about the sorrowful and painful feelings and memories that remain when somebody you loved leaves your life. Chris is confused and tries to work out what went wrong (similar to The Scientist), and in the 3rd verse it all collapses in a storm of sadness and self-loathing.

songs.title: A Message

description.plain:
“A Message” is a love song and the eighth track of Coldplay’s X&Y. The lyrics and melody were inspired by John Ireland’s 1664 hymn “My Song Is Love Unknown,” which is also Chris Martin’s favorite hymn.

Around the time that Coldplay was recording X&Y, Chris Martin’s father-in-law passed away. “A Message” may have been written for his wife Gwyneth Paltrow, who reportedly (and understandably) went into a depression after her father’s death (Martin supposedly wrote “Fix You” as a way of cheering her up).

songs.title: See You Soon

description.plain:
Third track from Coldplay’s second EP ‘The Blue Room’, released in 1999. The track would later become a staple of the band’s ‘A Rush Of Blood To The Head’ tour’s setlists, featuring on the DVD and CD ‘Live 2003’.

This song talks about betrayal of trust, either in a romantic or platonic relationship, and then how the speaker will try and move past it.

description.plain:
People of The Pride is the seventh track from Coldplay’s ninth studio album, Music of The Spheres. NME has said this has been said about the song,

“The song opens with a bone-crunching guitar riff – the band collectively cite Muse, Depeche Mode and Rammstein as inspirations – as it segues between serene, spacey chords and plenty of opportunities to let the hammer drop”.

It has been released on October 15th, The same date as the entire album.

songs.title: Miracles

description.plain:
Official soundtrack for Angelina Jolie’s movie as director “Unbroken”, premiered on December 25th, 2014.



The band, whose leader Chris Martin identifies himself religiously as “alltheist”, wrote the song by basing on the movie’s story: its main character is the American runner and Olympic athlete Louis Zamperini, who got captured by Japanese armies in 1943, during the battles of World War II in the Pacific Ocean, and sent to a prison camp for two years, throughout those “The Bird”, a Japanese sergeant, constantly beat Louis in a psychotic fury.

After his liberation, in 1949, in an effort to get over his trauma, Zamperini took part, together with his wife, to the Los Angeles Crusade, a campaign by the evangelist Billy Graham: the experience made the former athlete convert to Christianity and taught him the power of forgiveness and love, so he could have mercy on his persecutors.
As Louis wrote on his autobiography, “Devil at My Heels:”

I think the hardest thing in life is to forgive. Hate is self-destructive. If you hate someone, you’re not hurting the person you hate, you’re hurting yourself.

songs.title: Glass of Water

description.plain:
“Glass Of Water” is a song featured on Coldplay’s Prospekt’s March EP from 2008.

It was originally a song written during sessions for Coldplay’s fourth album, but didn’t make it onto the album’s final tracklisting. However, the song features heavily in the booklet of Viva La Vida Or Death And All His Friends despite being cut from the album.

The title appears on the big painting in the booklet’s centrefold, above some of the song’s lyrics, and the very first page of the album is a map of Brazil with more lyrics from Glass Of Water scribbled over it in crayon. However, the song’s lyrics have drastically changed since the painting was made.



  


In the chorus, the song shifts into an unusual 7/4 time signature, making it one of the band’s most complex songs. In general many of them were written during the VLVODAOHF era.

description.plain:
During the Manchester benefit concert One Love, Chris Martin and Jonny Buckland performed an acoustic cover of Oasis' 1995 anthem “Don’t Look Back In Anger”. He prefaced it by thanking Ariana Grande for hosting the concert and saying it was Britain’s turn to sing for her.



The song became representative of the defiant hopeful spirit of the city of Manchester in the wake of the bombings that happened at Ariana’s Dangerous Woman show on May 22. During the city’s vigil in the following days, a crowd spontaneously sang it during the one minute’s silence.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZT8sJuLjx7Y
